You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

A student programs a robot to move across a flat surface over the time interval <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 20"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds. The position of the robot at time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds is given by the parametric equations <math alttext="x of t equals, 3 t plus sine t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t equals, 3 times the cosine of, open parenthesis, t minus sine t, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in meters. The derivatives of these functions are given by <math alttext="x prime of t equals, 3 plus cosine t"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y prime of t equals, negative 3 times the sine of, open parenthesis, t minus sine t, close parenthesis, times open parenthesis, 1 minus cosine t, close parenthesis"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a)   Write an equation for the line tangent to the path of the robot at time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> seconds.
